context: Kirtland et al. (2003) evaluated TCE/CT degradation in the Savannah River site unsaturated zone through isotopic evaluation of δ13C of CAHs and δ13C and 14C of CO2. δ13C data indicated cDCE was always heavier than TCE (4–12‰) confirming its degradation was significant, however differentiation of possible biodegradation pathways was difficult. 14C–CO2 was modern and suggested that plant root-respired CO2 dominated, nevertheless 14C could provide direct measurement of CAH mineralization to CO2. Chu et al. (2004) demonstrated compound-specific isotopic fractionation in the laboratory for aerobic degradation of TCE, cDCE and VC was significantly smaller than for anaerobic reductive dechlorination. However, aerobic metabolic and cometabolic reaction fractionations were not sufficiently dissimilar for field differentiation. Abe et al. (2009) found that the isotopic enrichment factor ratios for C and Cl were substantially different for aerobic oxidation and reductive dechlorination of VC and cDCE and may be used to differentiate pathways. However, the recent work on JS666 aerobic oxidation of cDCE by Jennings et al. (2009) (discussed above) demonstrated an initial step of Cl-bond cleavage similar to that found in anaerobic reductive dechlorination that would cause isotopic-based pathway differentiation to be difficult.
